content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" standalone="yes" ?> <feed xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom">   <title>Mobile Web @ W3C - W3C</title>  <link rel="self" href="http://www.w3.org/Mobile/atom.xml"/>  <link href="http://www.w3.org/Mobile/"/>  <id>http://www.w3.org/Mobile/atom.xml</id>  <updated>2015-03-02T13:30:02+00:00</updated>  <generator uri="http://www.planetplanet.org/">Planet/2.0 +http://www.planetplanet.org</generator>   <entry xml:lang="en">   <title type="html">HTML5Apps at MWC&#8217;15</title>   <link href="http://html5apps-project.eu/2015/03/02/html5apps-at-mwc15/"/>   <id>http://html5apps-project.eu/?p=446</id>                 <updated>2015-03-02T13:16:24+00:00</updated>   <content type="html"><p>The HTML5Apps/W3C team is present at the <a href="http://www.mobileworldcongress.com/">Mobile World Congress 2015</a>. Dominique Haza\ufffd\ufffdl-Massieux is on-site at Fira Gran Via in Barcelona, Spain, from Monday 2 through Thursday 5 March 2015.</p> <p>The past year has seen significant milestones in W3C with the highlight being that HTML5 became a Web standard in late October of 2014. As a cornerstone of the Open Web Platform, HTML5 and other <a href="http://www.w3.org/2015/01/mobile-web-app-state/">standards for Web applications on mobile</a> continue to have a strong impact on a whole range of industries sectors, including payments, automotive and mobile (security).</p> <p>Just two weeks ago, the Vibration API reached the W3C recommendation status, which demonstrates that more and more Web apps get abilities of native smartphone software.</p> <p><a href="mailto:mcf@w3.org">Contact us</a> if you would like to discuss about the future of HTML5 applications while we&#8217;re at the Mobile World Congress. We are looking to working all together to close the gaps!</p><br />Filed under: <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/category/event/">Event</a>, <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/category/html5/">HTML5</a>, <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/category/html5apps/">html5apps</a>, <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/category/mobile/">Mobile</a>, <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/category/payment/">Payment</a>, <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/category/standardization/">Standardization</a>  <img alt="" border="0" src="http://pixel.wp.com/b.gif?host=html5apps-project.eu&blog=59373562&post=446&subd=html5appsproject&ref=&feed=1" width="1" height="1" /></content>   <author>    <name>mcforgue</name>    <uri>http://html5apps-project.eu</uri>   </author>   <source>    <title type="html">HTML5 Apps</title>    <link rel="self" href="http://html5apps-project.eu/feed/atom/"/>    <id>http://html5apps-project.eu/feed/atom/</id>   </source>  </entry>   <entry xml:lang="en-US">   <title type="html">W3C, Mobile World Congress 2015 and you</title>   <link href="http://www.w3.org/blog/2015/02/w3c-mobile-world-congress-2015-and-you/?pk_campaign=feed&pk_kwd=w3c-mobile-world-congress-2015-and-you"/>   <id>http://www.w3.org/blog/?p=14734</id>                 <updated>2015-02-23T19:04:53+00:00</updated>   <content type="html"><p>The past year has seen been one of significant milestones in W3C with the highlight being that HTML5 became a Recommendation in late October of 2014.  We have seen the Open Web Platform continuing to have an impact on a diverse set of Industries.  Within W3C this is manifest by the continued growth of our Digital Publishing Interest Group and the launch of both our Web Payments Interest Group and Automotive Working Group.  When you look at the hottest thing going on across Industries you have to recognize the Internet of Things as a movement that has gained an incredible amount of traction.  This work within W3C is happening in our Web of Things Interest Group. When you look at the Exhibitors and Attendees as well as the Sessions being held during Mobile World Congress 2015 there is a huge overlap in these conversations.  In fact, many of the GSMA Members that also Members of W3C are active participants in one or more of these groups &#8211; shouldn&#8217;t you be?</p> <p>W3C will be at Mobile World Congress 2015 but we will not have a booth this year.  We will be represented by Dominique Hazael-Massieux, our Mobile Guru, and J. Alan Bird, our Global Business Development Leader.  They will be on-site at Fira Gran Via in Barcelona, Spain from the afternoon of Monday, 02 March 2015 through Thursday, 05 March 2015.  If you are in any of the industries that are being touched by the Open Web Platform we&#8217;d love to have a conversation with you.  If you&#8217;re not in one of the Industries mentioned above but are curious about W3C, we&#8217;d also love to have a conversation with you.  The best way to schedule that is to send an e-mail to abird@w3.org.</p> <p> We look forward to seeing you in Barcelona and working together to help the Web reach its Full Potential!</p> <p><img src="https://www.w3.org/analytics/piwik/piwik.php?idsite=1&rec=1&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.w3.org%2Fblog%2F2015%2F02%2Fw3c-mobile-world-congress-2015-and-you%2F%3Fpk_campaign%3Dfeed%26pk_kwd%3Dw3c-mobile-world-congress-2015-and-you&action_name=W3C%2C+Mobile+World+Congress+2015+and+you&urlref=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.w3.org%2Fblog%2Ffeed%2F" width="0" height="0" alt="" /></p></content>   <author>    <name>W3C Blog: Mobile category</name>    <uri>http://www.w3.org/blog</uri>   </author>   <source>    <title type="html">W3C Blog \ufffd\ufffd Mobile</title>    <subtitle type="html">Leading the Web to its Full Potential</subtitle>    <link rel="self" href="http://www.w3.org/blog/category/mobile/feed/"/>    <id>tag:www.w3.org,2013:/QA//1</id>   </source>  </entry>   <entry xml:lang="en">   <title type="html">[New Edition!] Standards for Web apps on mobile \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd January 2015</title>   <link href="http://html5apps-project.eu/2015/02/02/new-edition-standards-for-web-apps-on-mobile-january-2015/"/>   <id>http://html5apps-project.eu/?p=422</id>                 <updated>2015-02-02T13:38:56+00:00</updated>   <content type="html"><p>A deliverable of the <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/">HTML5Apps</a> project, the January 2015 edition of the W3C <a href="http://www.w3.org/2014/10/mobile-web-app-state/">Standards for Web Applications on Mobile</a> includes a few changes and additions since October 2014. Notably, the <strong>document has been re-organized around the categories defined as</strong> <a href="http://www.w3.org/blog/2014/10/application-foundations-for-the-open-web-platform/"><em>Application Foundations</em></a>, a set of high-level grouping of features that highlight the needs from users and developers for the next generation of Web technologies.</p> <p>The other following changes in the Web platform since October 2014 are:</p> <dl> <dt><em>Published as First Public Working Draft</em></dt> <dd> <ul> <li><a href="http://w3ctag.github.io/packaging-on-the-web/">Packaging on the Web</a>, a joint work by the Web Applications Working Group and the Technical Architecture Group describing a Web-compatible format for packaging resources together, was published as a First Public Working Draft;</li> <li><a href="https://w3c.github.io/frame-timing/">Frame Timing</a>, an API developed by the Web Performance Working Group to provide detailed frame-per-second data on running Web applications, was published as a First Public Working Draft;</li> </ul> </dd> <dt><em>Returned to Working Draft</em></dt> <dd> <ul> <li>the <a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/resource-timing/">Resource Timing API</a> which had reached Candidate Recommendation status, had its scope expanded with a few additional properties and has thus returned to Working Draft status;</li> </ul> </dd> <dt><em>Reached Candidate Recommendation</em></dt> <dd> <ul> <li>the <a href="https://dvcs.w3.org/hg/dap/raw-file/tip/battery/Overview.html">Battery API</a> was republished as a Candidate Recommendation after a short Last Call review;</li> <li>the <a href="https://dvcs.w3.org/hg/webcrypto-api/raw-file/tip/spec/Overview.html">Web Cryptography API</a> reached Candidate Recommendation status;</li> </ul> </dd> <dt><em>Reached Proposed Recommendation</em></dt> <dd> <ul> <li>the <a href="http://dev.w3.org/html5/eventsource/">Server-Sent Events</a>, <a href="https://dvcs.w3.org/hg/pointerevents/raw-file/tip/pointerEvents.html">Pointer Events</a> and <a href="http://dev.w3.org/2009/dap/vibration/">Vibration</a> APIs reached Proposed Recommendation status;</li> </ul> </dd> <dt><em>Reached Recommendation</em></dt> <dd> <ul> <li>the <a href="http://w3c.github.io/IndexedDB/">Indexed Database API</a> was released as a W3C Recommendation;</li> </ul> </dd> <dt><em>Specification merged, split or abandoned</em></dt> <dd> <ul> <li>the <a href="https://fullscreen.spec.whatwg.org/">Fullscreen API</a>, previously co-developed in W3C by the Web Applications and CSS Working Groups, has been abandoned by these groups and has now fully moved to the WHATWG;</li> </ul> </dd> <dt><em>Newly tracked</em></dt> <dd> <ul> <li>the document now tracks the <a href="http://www.w3.org/2012/sysapps/web-alarms/">Task Scheduler API</a> from the <a href="http://www.w3.org/2012/sysapps/">System Applications Working Group</a> as an additional tool in the application lifecycle category; it allows to schedule a given task at a given time.</li> </ul> </dd> </dl> <p>This document is the 16th edition of this overview of mobile Web applications technologies. A live version of this document accepts contributions on <a href="https://github.com/w3c-webmob/mobile-web-app-standards/">the W3C Web and Mobile Interest Group Github repository</a>.</p><br />Filed under: <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/category/html5/">HTML5</a>, <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/category/html5apps/">html5apps</a>, <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/category/mobile/">Mobile</a>, <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/category/standardization/">Standardization</a>  <img alt="" border="0" src="http://pixel.wp.com/b.gif?host=html5apps-project.eu&blog=59373562&post=422&subd=html5appsproject&ref=&feed=1" width="1" height="1" /></content>   <author>    <name>mcforgue</name>    <uri>http://html5apps-project.eu</uri>   </author>   <source>    <title type="html">HTML5 Apps</title>    <link rel="self" href="http://html5apps-project.eu/feed/atom/"/>    <id>http://html5apps-project.eu/feed/atom/</id>   </source>  </entry>   <entry xml:lang="en">   <title type="html">[Web Payments] Next F2F meeting in Netherlands</title>   <link href="http://html5apps-project.eu/2015/01/26/web-payments-next-meeting-in-netherlands/"/>   <id>http://html5apps-project.eu/?p=408</id>                 <updated>2015-01-26T14:36:00+00:00</updated>   <content type="html"><p>The <a href="http://www.w3.org/Payments/IG/">Web Payments Interest Group</a> is organizing its second <a href="https://www.w3.org/Payments/IG/wiki/2014-02-02_Meeting_Page">face-face meeting</a> next month, on 2-4 February 2015, in Utrecht, The Netherlands. Hosted by <a href="https://www.rabobank.com/en/home/index.html">Rabobank</a>, this meeting is bringing a <a href="https://www.w3.org/2000/09/dbwg/details?group=73816&public=1">wide variety of stakeholders</a> to help set the directions of work and define the requirements needed to influence how Web Payments evolve.</p> <p>The mission of the Web Payments Interest Group, part of the <a href="http://www.w3.org/Payments/Activity.html">Web Payments Activity</a>, is to identify and leverage the conditions for greater uptake and wider use of Web Payments through the identification of standardization needs to increase interoperability between the different stakeholders and the different payment methods.</p><br />Filed under: <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/category/html5apps/">html5apps</a>, <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/category/payment/">Payment</a>, <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/category/standardization/">Standardization</a>  <img alt="" border="0" src="http://pixel.wp.com/b.gif?host=html5apps-project.eu&blog=59373562&post=408&subd=html5appsproject&ref=&feed=1" width="1" height="1" /></content>   <author>    <name>mcforgue</name>    <uri>http://html5apps-project.eu</uri>   </author>   <source>    <title type="html">HTML5 Apps</title>    <link rel="self" href="http://html5apps-project.eu/feed/atom/"/>    <id>http://html5apps-project.eu/feed/atom/</id>   </source>  </entry>   <entry xml:lang="en">   <title type="html">New W3C Trust &amp; Permissions Community Group</title>   <link href="http://html5apps-project.eu/2015/01/20/new-w3c-trust-permissions-community-group/"/>   <id>http://html5apps-project.eu/?p=310</id>                 <updated>2015-01-23T07:56:19+00:00</updated>   <content type="html"><p>As the Open Web Platform expands, and apps are developed that access various sensitive resources, new ways of managing permissions to access these resources are likely to arise. The newly formed <a href="http://www.w3.org/community/trustperms/">W3C Trust &amp; Permissions Community Group</a> will explore and evaluate such ways based upon experience with native and hybrid platforms, and drawing upon research studies. This follows on from the <a href="http://www.w3.org/2014/07/permissions/">Paris meeting on trust and permissions</a> held on 3-4 September 2014.</p> <p>Resources vary in sensitivity and timeliness, e.g. when and to whom a password should be disclosed is quite different from when access to the user\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds webcam should be granted. Similarly, modes of obtaining user permission vary, including asking users upfront for permission when an app is installed or first run (exemplified in Android and Windows) or asking users for permission when the application is attempting to use a given capability (exemplified in iOS) and permission can even be obtained after the fact by inviting the user to continue or to cancel an action after it has occurred, i.e. asking for forgiveness rather than permission. In some cases, the user&#8217;s actions can be taken as implicitly granting permission, such as the Windows file chooser dialog. A further approach is for users to delegate decisions on permissions to a trusted 3rd party.</p> <p>The goal of this CG is to develop and articulate best practices for which modes of obtaining permission best match which resource types, and make these best practices available to both platform developers (browser and operating system vendors) and app developers. Ideally the APIs offered to apps to obtain permission to access resources should be consistent across platforms, while allowing platforms the flexibility to present a user experience that meets each platform\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds needs.</p> <p>The scope of this Community Group is limited to discussion and guidance on best practices, to review draft APIs from individual WG&#8217;s, and pre-standardisation work on promising ideas for better user experience obtaining permission, including trusted UI and trust delegation per <a href="http://research.microsoft.com/pubs/152495/user-driven-access-control-nov2011.pdf">Roesner et al</a>. Work on best practices will focus on the kinds of resources that need protection, the enumeration of good ways to obtain user permission, to dis-recommend permission models that are known to be problematic, and to recommend the preferred user experience for a given kind of resource. The main focus is on the Open Web Platform, but packaged apps are not excluded.</p> <p>W3C Community Groups are open to anyone to join, free of charge. If you have expertise in regard to handling trust and permissions for applications, you will be very welcome as a new member of the <a href="http://www.w3.org/community/trustperms/">Trust &amp; Permissions CG</a>.</p><br />Filed under: <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/category/html5apps/">html5apps</a>  <img alt="" border="0" src="http://pixel.wp.com/b.gif?host=html5apps-project.eu&blog=59373562&post=310&subd=html5appsproject&ref=&feed=1" width="1" height="1" /></content>   <author>    <name>draggett</name>    <uri>http://html5apps-project.eu</uri>   </author>   <source>    <title type="html">HTML5 Apps</title>    <link rel="self" href="http://html5apps-project.eu/feed/atom/"/>    <id>http://html5apps-project.eu/feed/atom/</id>   </source>  </entry>   <entry xml:lang="en-US">   <title type="html">This week: W3C CEO on after HTML5, #bbd14, @W3C-PO protocol droid, No CAPTCHA ReCAPTCHA, etc.</title>   <link href="http://www.w3.org/blog/2014/12/this-week-w3c-ceo-on-after-html5-bbd14-w3c-po-protocol-droid-no-captcha-recaptcha-etc/?pk_campaign=feed&pk_kwd=this-week-w3c-ceo-on-after-html5-bbd14-w3c-po-protocol-droid-no-captcha-recaptcha-etc"/>   <id>http://www.w3.org/blog/?p=14588</id>                 <updated>2014-12-05T17:06:21+00:00</updated>   <content type="html"><p><em>This is the <strong>28 November &#8211; 5 December 2014</strong> edition of a &#8220;weekly digest of W3C news and trends&#8221; that I prepare for the W3C Membership and <a href="mailto:public-w3c-digest-request@w3.org?subject=subscribe">public-w3c-digest</a> mailing list (publicly <a href="http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-w3c-digest/">archived</a>). This digest aggregates information about W3C and W3C technology from online media \ufffd\ufffd\ufffda snapshot of how W3C and its work is perceived in online media.</em></p> <h2>W3C and HTML5 related Twitter trends</h2> <p><em>[What was tweeted frequently, or caught my attention. Most <strong>recent</strong> first]</em></p> <ul> <li>(<code>35</code>) <strong>Conference</strong>: <a href="http://events.html5j.org/conference/2015/1/">HTML5 conference</a>, 2015-01-25, Tokyo Denki University Senju campus </li> <li>(<code>435</code>) <strong>ZDNet</strong>: <a href="http://www.zdnet.com/article/now-html-5-is-finished-w3c-boss-jeff-jaffe-discusses-what-comes-next/">Now HTML 5 is finished, W3C boss Jeff Jaffe discusses what comes next</a> </li> <li>(<code>50</code>) <strong>Star Wars tweet</strong>: <a href="http://twitter.com/DanEngler/status/539885026083872770">The worst character in the new Star Wars is @W3C-PO, a protocol droid that waits 4 years AFTER you jump to lightspeed to plot your course.</a> </li> <li>(<code>60</code>) <strong>Community Group</strong>: <a href="http://www.w3.org/community/colourblindness/2014/11/27/call-for-participation-in-colour-blindness-accessibility-community-group/">Call for Participation in Colour blindness accessibility Community Group</a> </li> <li>(<code>70</code>) <strong>Blue Beanie Day</strong>: <a href="https://twitter.com/w3c/status/538331493215383552">If #webstandards make your life easier, share a #bbd14 blue beanie photo, learn about Web standards, participate!</a> <a href="https://vimeo.com/110256895">https://vimeo.com/110256895</a> </li> <li>(<code>55</code>) <strong>Hackathon</strong>: <a href="http://osl.ugr.es/2014/12/01/6250/">@tripu y @chaals sobre est\ufffd\ufffdndares y W3C #w3cugr #ttwf</a> [28 November, University of Granada; Web standards, W3C, Test the Web Forward hackathon with Antonio Olmo and chaals] </li> </ul> <h2>Net Neutrality &amp; Open Web</h2> <ul> <li>(<code>145</code>) <strong>Mozilla Advocacy</strong>: <a href="https://advocacy.mozilla.org/">Protect the Free and Open Web, protect Net Neutrality</a> </li> <li>(<code>561</code>) <strong>John Gruber</strong>: <a href="http://daringfireball.net/2014/11/native_apps_are_part_of_the_web">Native Apps Are Part of the Web</a> </li> <li>(<code>60</code>) <strong>Jesse von Doom</strong>: <a href="https://medium.com/cash-music/more-than-royalties-9fe0358dced4">It\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds time we bring the open web to music</a> </li> <li>(<code>23K</code>) <strong>Google</strong>: <a href="http://googleonlinesecurity.blogspot.fr/2014/12/are-you-robot-introducing-no-captcha.html">Are you a robot? Introducing \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdNo CAPTCHA reCAPTCHA\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd</a> </li> </ul> <h2>W3C in the Press (or blogs)</h2> <p><strong>4</strong> articles since the last Digest; a selection follows. You may read all articles in our <a href="http://www.w3.org/Press/Articles">Press Clippings</a> page.</p> <ul> <li><strong>wspa.com</strong> (3 December), <a href="http://www.wspa.com/story/27535509/tim-berners-lee-awarded-the-gottlieb-duttweiler-prize-2015">Tim Berners-Lee Awarded the Gottlieb Duttweiler Prize 2015</a></li> <li><strong>Access iQ</strong> (1 December), <a href="http://www.accessiq.org/news/w3c-column/2014/12/w3c-web-accessibility-initiative-2014-in-review">W3C Web Accessibility Initiative: 2014 in review</a></li> <li><strong>ZDNet</strong> (30 November), <a href="http://www.zdnet.com/article/now-html-5-is-finished-w3c-boss-jeff-jaffe-discusses-what-comes-next/">Now HTML 5 is finished, W3C boss Jeff Jaffe discusses what comes next</a></li> <li><strong>Gov.uk Government Technology</strong> (27 November), <a href="https://governmenttechnology.blog.gov.uk/2014/11/27/world-wide-web-consortium-w3c-membership-for-hm-government/">World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) membership for HM Government</a></li> </ul> <p><img src="https://www.w3.org/analytics/piwik/piwik.php?idsite=1&rec=1&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.w3.org%2Fblog%2F2014%2F12%2Fthis-week-w3c-ceo-on-after-html5-bbd14-w3c-po-protocol-droid-no-captcha-recaptcha-etc%2F%3Fpk_campaign%3Dfeed%26pk_kwd%3Dthis-week-w3c-ceo-on-after-html5-bbd14-w3c-po-protocol-droid-no-captcha-recaptcha-etc&action_name=This+week%3A+W3C+CEO+on+after+HTML5%2C+%23bbd14%2C+%40W3C-PO+protocol+droid%2C+No+CAPTCHA+ReCAPTCHA%2C+etc.&urlref=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.w3.org%2Fblog%2Ffeed%2F" width="0" height="0" alt="" /></p></content>   <author>    <name>W3C Blog: Mobile category</name>    <uri>http://www.w3.org/blog</uri>   </author>   <source>    <title type="html">W3C Blog \ufffd\ufffd Mobile</title>    <subtitle type="html">Leading the Web to its Full Potential</subtitle>    <link rel="self" href="http://www.w3.org/blog/category/mobile/feed/"/>    <id>tag:www.w3.org,2013:/QA//1</id>   </source>  </entry>   <entry xml:lang="en">   <title type="html">[New edition!] Standards for Web apps on mobile \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd October 2014</title>   <link href="http://html5apps-project.eu/2014/12/02/new-edition-standards-for-web-apps-on-mobile-october-2014/"/>   <id>http://html5apps-project.eu/?p=371</id>                 <updated>2014-12-03T00:03:57+00:00</updated>   <content type="html"><p><img class="alignright size-full wp-image-3" src="http://www.w3.org/2014/11/webapp-sm.png" alt="Mobile Web Apps roadmap illustrtion" /></p> <p>A deliverable of the <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/">HTML5Apps</a> project, the October 2014 edition of the W3C <a href="http://www.w3.org/2014/10/mobile-web-app-state/">Standards for Web Applications on Mobile</a> includes changes and additions since July 2014, notably emerging work such as:</p> <ul> <li>the Second Screen Presentation Working Group API to request display of content on an external screen,</li> <li>a draft API from the Web Bluetooth Community Group,</li> <li>Device APIs Working Group work on a generic pattern for sensors APIs,</li> <li>as well as work on an API to manage permissions across other APIs.</li> </ul> <p>This document is the 15th edition of this overview of mobile Web applications technologies. A live version of this document accepts contributions on <a href="https://github.com/w3c-webmob/mobile-web-app-standards/">the W3C Web and Mobile Interest Group Github repository</a>.</p><br />Filed under: <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/category/html5/">HTML5</a>, <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/category/html5apps/">html5apps</a>, <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/category/mobile/">Mobile</a>, <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/category/standardization/">Standardization</a>  <img alt="" border="0" src="http://pixel.wp.com/b.gif?host=html5apps-project.eu&blog=59373562&post=371&subd=html5appsproject&ref=&feed=1" width="1" height="1" /></content>   <author>    <name>mcforgue</name>    <uri>http://html5apps-project.eu</uri>   </author>   <source>    <title type="html">HTML5 Apps</title>    <link rel="self" href="http://html5apps-project.eu/feed/atom/"/>    <id>http://html5apps-project.eu/feed/atom/</id>   </source>  </entry>   <entry xml:lang="en">   <title type="html">HTML5 is a Web standard!</title>   <link href="http://html5apps-project.eu/2014/10/28/html5-is-a-web-standard/"/>   <id>http://html5apps-project.eu/?p=351</id>                 <updated>2014-10-28T17:19:56+00:00</updated>   <content type="html"><p><a href="https://html5appsproject.files.wordpress.com/2013/10/html5_badge_512-e1382192921467.png"><img class="alignright size-full wp-image-3" src="https://html5appsproject.files.wordpress.com/2013/10/html5_badge_512-e1382192921467.png?w=176" alt="HTML5 logo" /></a>The W3C HTML5Apps team is very proud to relay the good news that HTML5 reached the W3C Web standard status today!</p> <p>HTML5 defines the fifth major revision of the Hypertext Markup Language (HTML), the format used to build Web pages and applications, and the cornerstone of the Open Web Platform.</p> <p>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd<em>Today we think nothing of watching video and audio natively in the browser, and nothing of running a browser on a phone,</em>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd said <strong>Tim Berners-Lee, W3C Director and Web inventor</strong>. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd<em>We expect to be able to share photos, shop, read the news, and look up information anywhere, on any device. Though they remain invisible to most users, HTML5 and the Open Web Platform are driving these growing user expectations.</em>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd</p> <p>HTML5 brings to the Web video and audio tracks without needing plugins; programmatic access to a resolution-dependent bitmap canvas, which is useful for rendering graphs, game graphics, or other visual images on the fly; native support for scalable vector graphics (SVG) and math (MathML); annotations important for East Asian typography (Ruby); features to enable accessibility of rich applications; and much more.</p> <div id="attachment_348" class="wp-caption alignright"><a href="http://vimeo.com/w3c/buildstandards"><img class="wp-image-348 " src="https://html5appsproject.files.wordpress.com/2014/10/w3c20-video.png?w=221&h=107" alt="W3C20 video" width="221" height="107" /></a><p class="wp-caption-text">Web standards for the future</p></div> <p>For news on what\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds next after HTML5, see W3C CEO Jeff Jaffe\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds blog post on &#8220;<a href="http://www.w3.org/blog/2014/10/application-foundations-for-the-open-web-platform/">Application Foundations for the Open Web Platform&#8221;</a>.</p> <p>Find out in less than 2 minutes why Web Standards for the future are important by watching the\ufffd\ufffd <a href="http://vimeo.com/w3c/buildstandards">Web standards for the future</a> video.</p><br />Filed under: <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/category/html5/">HTML5</a>, <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/category/html5apps/">html5apps</a>, <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/category/standardization/">Standardization</a>  <img alt="" border="0" src="http://pixel.wp.com/b.gif?host=html5apps-project.eu&blog=59373562&post=351&subd=html5appsproject&ref=&feed=1" width="1" height="1" /></content>   <author>    <name>mcforgue</name>    <uri>http://html5apps-project.eu</uri>   </author>   <source>    <title type="html">HTML5 Apps</title>    <link rel="self" href="http://html5apps-project.eu/feed/atom/"/>    <id>http://html5apps-project.eu/feed/atom/</id>   </source>  </entry>   <entry xml:lang="en">   <title type="html">Web Payments Activity Launched</title>   <link href="http://html5apps-project.eu/2014/10/15/web-payments-activity-launched/"/>   <id>http://html5apps-project.eu/?p=325</id>                 <updated>2014-10-15T19:36:18+00:00</updated>   <content type="html"><p>HTML5Apps/W3C announced today a new <a href="http://www.w3.org/Payments/">Web Payments Initiative</a> to integrate payments seamlessly into the Open Web Platform.</p> <p>W3C <strong>calls upon all industry stakeholders</strong> \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdbanks, credit card companies, governments, mobile network operators, payment solution providers, technology companies, retailers, and content creators\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd <strong>to join the</strong> <a href="http://www.w3.org/Payments/IG/">new Payments Interest Group</a> and leverage the unique ability of the Web to bridge ecosystem diversity and reach users everywhere, on any device.</p> <p>The result will be new business opportunities, an improved user experience for online transactions, reduced fraud, and increased interoperability among traditional solutions and future payment innovations.</p> <p>Read the full press release (<a href="http://www.w3.org/2014/10/payments.html.en">in English</a> and in <a href="https://html5appsproject.files.wordpress.com/2014/10/html5apps-w3c-paiementsweb-cp-15oct14.pdf">French</a> ) including <a href="http://www.w3.org/2014/10/payments.html.en#testimonials">testimonials from W3C Members </a>Bloomberg, Gemalto, GRIN Technologies, Ingenico Group, NACS, Rabobank, and Yandex.</p><br />Filed under: <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/category/html5apps/">html5apps</a>, <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/category/payment/">Payment</a>, <a href="http://html5apps-project.eu/category/standardization/">Standardization</a>  <img alt="" border="0" src="http://pixel.wp.com/b.gif?host=html5apps-project.eu&blog=59373562&post=325&subd=html5appsproject&ref=&feed=1" width="1" height="1" /></content>   <author>    <name>mcforgue</name>    <uri>http://html5apps-project.eu</uri>   </author>   <source>    <title type="html">HTML5 Apps</title>    <link rel="self" href="http://html5apps-project.eu/feed/atom/"/>    <id>http://html5apps-project.eu/feed/atom/</id>   </source>  </entry>   <entry xml:lang="en-US">   <title type="html">This week: CSS 20th anniversary, autowebplatform progress, TimBL\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds keynote, Physical Web, etc.</title>   <link href="http://www.w3.org/blog/2014/10/this-week-css-20th-anniversary-autowebplatform-progress-timbls-keynote-physical-web-etc/?pk_campaign=feed&pk_kwd=this-week-css-20th-anniversary-autowebplatform-progress-timbls-keynote-physical-web-etc"/>   <id>http://www.w3.org/blog/?p=14494</id>                 <updated>2014-10-10T14:31:48+00:00</updated>   <content type="html"><p><em>This is the <strong>3-10 October 2014</strong> edition of a &#8220;weekly digest of W3C news and trends&#8221; that I prepare for the W3C Membership and <a href="mailto:public-w3c-digest-request@w3.org?subject=subscribe">public-w3c-digest</a> mailing list (publicly <a href="http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-w3c-digest/">archived</a>). This digest aggregates information about W3C and W3C technology from online media \ufffd\ufffd\ufffda snapshot of how W3C and its work is perceived in online media.</em></p> <h2>W3C and HTML5 related Twitter trends</h2> <p><em>[What was tweeted frequently, or caught my attention.</em> <em>Most <strong>recent</strong> first]</em></p> <ul> <li>(<code>600</code>) <strong>Dev.Opera</strong>: <a href="https://dev.opera.com/articles/css-twenty-years-hakon/">CSS: It was twenty years ago today \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd an interview with H\ufffd\ufffdkon Wium Lie</a> </li> <li>(<code>80</code>) <strong>Automotive</strong>: <a href="http://blogs.intel.com/iot/2014/10/accelerating-adoption-web-technologies-automotive-industry/">Accelerating the Adoption of Web Technologies in the Automotive Industry</a> </li> <li>(<code>35</code>) <strong>HTML5 wearable</strong>: <a href="http://twitter.com/html5shirt/status/520250765177151488">Hoodie season is here. Bundle up and wear your HTML5 badge proudly! @html5 @w3c @html5guy</a> </li> <li>(<code>620</code>) <strong>Hybrid apps</strong>: <a href="http://readwrite.com/2014/10/02/html5-apple-ios-8-wkwebview">HTML5 Has A New Best Friend\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdAnd It&#8217;s Apple, Not Google</a> </li> <li>(25) <strong>Hybrid apps</strong>: <a href="https://www.scirra.com/blog/ashley/12/html5-does-not-have-a-new-best-friend">HTML5 does not have a new best friend</a> </li> </ul> <h2>Open Web &amp; net neutrality</h2> <ul> <li><strong>The New York Times | Bits</strong>: <a href="http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/10/08/tim-berners-lee-web-creator-defends-net-neutrality/">Tim Berners-Lee, Web Creator, Defends Net Neutrality</a> &#8211; 8 October 2014 </li> <li><strong>Scott Jenson (Google)</strong>: <a href="http://google.github.io/physical-web/">Physical Web, an open web spec to &#8220;Walk up and use anything\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd</a> &#8211; 3 October 2014 </li> <li><strong>Open Web Board</strong>: <a href="http://news.kddi.com/kddi/corporate/english/newsrelease/2014/10/03/684.html">KDDI Develops Creative Platform for Firefox OS Developers</a> &#8211; 3 October 2014 </li> </ul> <h2>W3C in the Press (or blogs)</h2> <p><strong>22</strong> articles since the last Digest; a selection follows. You may read all articles in our <a href="http://www.w3.org/Press/Articles">Press Clippings</a> page.</p> <ul> <li><strong>Gizmodo</strong> (10 October), <a href="http://gizmodo.com/css-is-20-years-old-today-1644721207">CSS Is 20 Years Old Today</a> </li> <li><strong>CNET</strong> (9 October), <a href="http://www.cnet.com/news/imgur-gifv-format-speeds-up-viral-image-sharing/">The tired GIF gets a modern-day makeover</a></li> <li><strong>Motherboard</strong> (8 October), <a href="http://motherboard.vice.com/read/tim-berners-lee-calls-for-net-neutrality-and-data-ownership">Tim Berners-Lee Wants a World Wide Web Where Our Data Works for Us</a></li> <li><strong>The Guardian | Technology</strong> (8 October), <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/oct/08/sir-tim-berners-lee-speaks-out-on-data-ownership">Sir Tim Berners-Lee speaks out on data ownership</a></li> <li><strong>Intel IoT Blog</strong> (6 October), <a href="http://blogs.intel.com/iot/2014/10/accelerating-adoption-web-technologies-automotive-industry/">Accelerating the Adoption of Web Technologies in the Automotive Industry</a></li> </ul> <p><img src="https://www.w3.org/analytics/piwik/piwik.php?idsite=1&rec=1&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.w3.org%2Fblog%2F2014%2F10%2Fthis-week-css-20th-anniversary-autowebplatform-progress-timbls-keynote-physical-web-etc%2F%3Fpk_campaign%3Dfeed%26pk_kwd%3Dthis-week-css-20th-anniversary-autowebplatform-progress-timbls-keynote-physical-web-etc&action_name=This+week%3A+CSS+20th+anniversary%2C+autowebplatform+progress%2C+TimBL%E2%80%99s+keynote%2C+Physical+Web%2C+etc.&urlref=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.w3.org%2Fblog%2Ffeed%2F"
